--- title: "Correlations in R" author: "Arvind Venkatadri" date: "2023-04-13" abstract: Tests, Tables, and Graphs for Correlations in R code-tools: true --- # Introduction We will create Tables for Correlations, and graphs for Correlations in R. As always, we will consistently use the [**Project Mosaic**](https://mosaic-web.org) ecosystem of packages in R (`mosaic`, `mosaicData` and `ggformula`). ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/setup_ba2cc11e3508bb79383b7f74d0700b05'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(mosaic) # package for stats, simulations, and basic plots library(mosaicData) # package containing datasets library(ggformula) # package for professional looking plots, that use the formula interface from mosaic library(NHANES) # survey data collected by the US National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) library(corrplot) # For Correlogram plots ``` ::: ::: callout-important Note the standard method for all commands from the `mosaic/ggformula` packages: `goal( y ~ x | z, data = mydata, â€¦)` ::: ## Case Study -1: Dataset from `mosaicData` Let us inspect what datasets are available in the package `mosaicData`. Run this command in your Console: ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_f287f78803dd428d5d88a22cce054556'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Run in Console data(package = "mosaicData") ``` ::: The popup tab shows a lot of datasets we could use. Let us continue to use the famous `Galton` dataset and `inspect` it: ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_b0edde4faa151627d0531a41b7552636'} ```{.r .cell-code} data("Galton") inspect(Galton) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` categorical variables: name class levels n missing 1 family factor 197 898 0 2 sex factor 2 898 0 distribution 1 185 (1.7%), 166 (1.2%), 66 (1.2%) ... 2 M (51.8%), F (48.2%) quantitative variables: name class min Q1 median Q3 max mean sd n missing 1 father numeric 62 68 69.0 71.0 78.5 69.232851 2.470256 898 0 2 mother numeric 58 63 64.0 65.5 70.5 64.084410 2.307025 898 0 3 height numeric 56 64 66.5 69.7 79.0 66.760690 3.582918 898 0 4 nkids integer 1 4 6.0 8.0 15.0 6.135857 2.685156 898 0 ``` ::: ::: The `inspect` command already gives us a series of statistical measures of different variables of interest. As discussed previously, we can retain the output of `inspect` and use it in our reports: (there are ways of dressing up these tables too) ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/Galton-inspect_adaecfd9a6b64c00e24caafb5cd0fa53'} ```{.r .cell-code} galton_describe <- inspect(Galton) galton_describe$categorical ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} galton_describe$quantitative ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: Try `help("Galton")` in your Console. The dataset is described as: > A data frame with 898 observations on the following variables.\ > - `family` a factor with levels for each family\ > - `father` the father's height (in inches)\ > - `mother` the mother's height (in inches)\ > - `sex` the child's sex: F or M\ > - `height` the child's height as an adult (in inches)\ > - `nkids` the number of adult children in the family, or, at least, > the number whose heights Galton recorded. There is a lot of Description generated by the `mosaic::inspect()` command ! What can we say about the dataset and its variables? How big is the dataset? How many variables? What types are they, Quant or Qual? If they are Qual, what are the *levels*? Are they *ordered* levels? Discuss! ## Correlations and Plots What Questions might we have, that we could answer with a Statistical Measure, or Correlation chart? Q.1 Which are the variables that have significant pair-wise correlations? What polarity are these correlations? ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_1c183c6db208a8820996455ba686b3a2'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Pulling out the list of Quant variables from NHANES galton_quant <- galton_describe$quantitative galton_quant$name ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "father" "mother" "height" "nkids" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} GGally::ggpairs( Galton, columns = c("father", "mother", "height", "nkids"), diag = list("densityDiag"), title = "Galton Data Correlations Plot" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Can we plot a Correlogram for this dataset? ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_3597b5af14303aba38ff4fb28c61bc2e'} ```{.r .cell-code} #library(corrplot) galton_num_var <- Galton %>% select(father, mother, height, nkids) galton_cor <- cor(galton_num_var) galton_cor %>% corrplot(method = "ellipse", type = "lower", main = "Correlogram for Galton dataset") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Clearly `height` is positively correlated to `father` and `mother`; interestingly, `height` is negatively correlated ( slightly) with `nkids`. Q.2: Let us confirm with a test: ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_fd1305c897ff261956e9cbe43748f977'} ```{.r .cell-code} mosaic::cor_test(height ~ father, data = Galton) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: height and father t = 8.5737, df = 896, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.2137851 0.3347455 sample estimates: cor 0.2753548 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_2ac934f72edb6cbba2a5d8a0155179f1'} ```{.r .cell-code} mosaic::cor_test(height ~ mother, data = Galton) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: height and mother t = 6.1628, df = 896, p-value = 1.079e-09 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.1380554 0.2635982 sample estimates: cor 0.2016549 ``` ::: ::: Q.3 What does this correlation look when split by `sex` of Child? We will use the `mosaic` function `cor_test` to get these results: ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_94393dfd7d641afcf79c78213171d367'} ```{.r .cell-code} # For the sons mosaic::cor_test(height ~ father, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "M")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: height and father t = 9.1498, df = 463, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.3114667 0.4656805 sample estimates: cor 0.3913174 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cor_test(height ~ mother, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "M")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: height and mother t = 7.628, df = 463, p-value = 1.367e-13 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.2508178 0.4125305 sample estimates: cor 0.3341309 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # For the daughters cor_test(height ~ father, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "F")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: height and father t = 10.719, df = 431, p-value < 2.2e-16 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.3809944 0.5300812 sample estimates: cor 0.4587605 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cor_test(height ~ mother, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "F")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: height and mother t = 6.8588, df = 431, p-value = 2.421e-11 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.2261463 0.3962226 sample estimates: cor 0.3136984 ``` ::: ::: Q.4. How can we show this correlation in a set of Scatter Plots + Regression Lines? Can we recreate Galton's famous diagram? ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_058c02599c56fd9796b44f6e65b9146c'} ```{.r .cell-code} # For the sons gf_point(height ~ father, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "M")) %>% gf_smooth(method = "lm") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} gf_point(height ~ mother, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "M")) %>% gf_smooth(method = "lm") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # For the daughters gf_point(height ~ father, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "F")) %>% gf_smooth(method = "lm") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} gf_point(height ~ mother, data = Galton %>% filter(sex == "F")) %>% gf_smooth(method = "lm") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-4.png){width=672} ::: ::: An approximation to Galton's famous plot (see Wikipedia): ::: {.cell hash='correlations_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_5c1047c25515c3935fb329392f3dec4e'} ```{.r .cell-code} gf_point(height ~ (father + mother)/2, data = Galton) %>% gf_smooth(method = "lm") %>% gf_density_2d(n = 8) %>% gf_abline(slope = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](correlations_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: How would you interpret this plot? ## Case Study -2: Dataset from `NHANES` We will "live code" this in class! # Conclusion We have a decent Correlations related *workflow* in R:\ - load the dataset\ - `inspect` the dataset, identify Quant and Qual variables\ - Develop Pair-Wise plots + Correlations using `GGally::ggpairs()`\ - Develop Correlogram `corrplot::corrplot`\ - Check everything with a `cor_test`\ - Plot scatter plots using `gf_point` if needed.\ - Add extra lines using `gf_abline()` to compare hypotheses that you may have.
